data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A partner, especially one of a pair or team associated under the buddy system.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Friend or comrade; chum. Used as a form of familiar address, especially for a man or boy.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To associate as a buddy or buddies.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: buddied around with the older guys.

data.text: To ingratiate oneself, as by presuming friendship.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: buddied up to the coach in hopes of making the team.

data.attributionText: from Wiktionary, Creative Commons Attribution/Share-Alike License.
from Wiktionary, Creative Commons Attribution/Share-Alike License.

data.text: An <xref>informal</xref> and friendly address to a <xref>stranger</xref>; a friendly <xref>placeholder</xref> name for a person one does not know.
data.attributionText: from Wiktionary, Creative Commons Attribution/Share-Alike License.
from Wiktionary, Creative Commons Attribution/Share-Alike License.
